Internal Controls are the program manuals policies and procedures. The ICs describe the program manual’s objectives, and officials charged with management and oversight. The ICs ensure the: a. Mission and program objectives are clearly delineated and key terms are deﬁned; and b. Program operations are in conformance with applicable laws and regulations. (
) To conform to the new Internal Controls standards: a. Former subsection

, Functional Statement, is retitled to Program Scope and to properly reﬂect the information communicated in the subsection. The subsection clearly delineates the program manual’s mission, objectives, and goals. b. New subsection
is added to provide the legal authorities for the program manual (Organization and Staffing, Criminal Investigation). c. New subsection
is added as a compiled list of the terms and acronyms used within the program manual (Organization and Staffing, Criminal Investigation). (
) IRM
is revised in its entirety.

Subsections 1.1.19.1 through 1.1.19.1.2 reﬂect the IRS requirement that IR manuals address Controls (ICs). The ICs mandate is outlined in The Heightened Awareness, Sensitivity, and Understanding of Internal Controls memo dated September 14, 2016. Internal Controls are the program manuals policies and procedures. The ICs describe the program manual’s objectives, and officials charged with management and oversight. The ICs ensure the:
Mission and program objectives are clearly delineated and key terms are deﬁned; and Program operations are in conformance with applicable laws and regulations.
a. Former subsection

, Functional Statement, is retitled to Program Scope and Objectives to properly reﬂect the information communicated in the subsection. The subsection clearly delineates the program manual’s mission, objectives, and goals. b. New subsection
is added to provide the legal authorities for the program manual (Organization and Staffing, Criminal Investigation). c. New subsection
is added as a compiled list of the terms and acronyms used within the program manual (Organization and Staffing, Criminal Investigation).
All Divisions and Functions
Table of Contents

) The mission of Criminal Investigation (CI) is to serve the American public investigating potential criminal violations of the Internal Revenue Code and related ﬁnancial crimes in a manner that fosters conﬁdence in the tax and compliance with the law. (

) While tax enforcement is clearly the core mission, CI also makes signiﬁcant contributions to other important national law enforcement efforts. Criminal vestigation’s participation in joint investigations has helped lead to major convictions on high proﬁle cases involving such issues as political corporate fraud, narcotics trafficking, and terrorist ﬁnancing. (
) Criminal Investigation is staffed with approximately
employees whose dedicated efforts have earned CI a reputation as the premier ﬁnancial gative agency in the world. (

) To accomplish the mission, CI: a. Develops and implements measures that balance customer appropriate to law enforcement, employee satisfaction and business results. b. Ensures that criminal enforcement is an essential part of an tax compliance strategy. c. Fulﬁlls the expectation of honest taxpayers that tax evaders will be nally prosecuted. d. Provides support to the US Attorney’s Office by investigating ﬁnancial crimes appropriate to CI’s jurisdiction and participating in joint tive task forces. e. Provides advice to Congressional Committees on legislation, litigation, and Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) matters and other requests as they relate to CI provides, when necessary, personal tion for IRS employees. f. Ensures all CI employees are properly trained to fulﬁll their mission. g. Identiﬁes, examines, and addresses the organization’s employment practices, policies, guidelines, and procedures to ensure that all employees and applicants for employment achieve equal opportunity every facet of CI’s programs, activities, and services as directed by IRS.

To accomplish the mission, CI: a. Develops and implements measures that balance customer satisfaction appropriate to law enforcement, employee satisfaction and business results. b. Ensures that criminal enforcement is an essential part of an integrated tax compliance strategy. c. Fulﬁlls the expectation of honest taxpayers that tax evaders will be nally prosecuted. d. Provides support to the US Attorney’s Office by investigating ﬁnancial crimes appropriate to CI’s jurisdiction and participating in joint investiga

tive task forces. e. Provides advice to Congressional Committees on legislation, regulation, litigation, and Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) matters and other requests as they relate to CI provides, when necessary, personal tion for IRS employees. f. Ensures all CI employees are properly trained to fulﬁll their mission. g. Identiﬁes, examines, and addresses the organization’s employment practices, policies, guidelines, and procedures to ensure that all employees and applicants for employment achieve equal opportunity in every facet of CI’s programs, activities, and services as directed by the IRS.
See IRM 9.1.2, Authority, IRM 9.1.1, Mission, and IRM Chapter 1.4 – Resource Managers for the delegated authority related to IRM 1.1.19.

) The Chief, Criminal Investigation, is the highest ranking executive within IRS- CI. The Chief, CI, reports to the Deputy Commissioner, Services and Enforcement. The Chief, CI, is responsible for the full range of planning, managing, directing, and executing the worldwide activities of CI. The Chief, CI, together with the Deputy Chief, directly supervises the Directors of the offices, as well as the Area Directors, Field Operations. (
) The Office of the Chief includes the following sections: • Chief of Staff • Deputy Chief of Staff • C&E • EDI • RPE (

) The Chief of Staff, together with the Deputy Chief of Staff, manages the and Deputy Chief’s official appointments, speaking engagements, calendar items, and duties associated with the selection of senior management personnel. Additionally, the Chief of Staff supervises the Commissioner’s Pro- tection Detail which provides daily executive protection to the IRS Commissioner. (

) Communications and Education plans, coordinates, and produces tions products and tools for CI. Communications and Education provides a wide range of products and services to help achieve communications goals a variety of audiences; employees, managers, the media, tax, accounting business professionals, and other external and internal stakeholders. nications and Education also coordinates ﬁeld office publicity through the who are special agents trained in media relations. Communications and Education is also the home to CI’s Legislative Liaison who manages and enhances CI’s relationship with members of Congress, ensures CI sections informed of pending legislation affecting their areas, and responds to sional inquiries and correspondence. (

) Equity, Diversity & Inclusion is responsible for identifying trends and issues of an EEO and diversity nature, and potential barriers to equal employment op- portunity within CI. Equity, Diversity & Inclusion’s responsibilities include educating management and employees on equity, diversity & inclusion, how resolve complaints and conﬂict in the workplace, and providing observation recruitment, outreach, promotion, retention, and leadership initiatives, thereby improving workforce demographics to achieve equal opportunity.
Organization and (

) Review and Program Evaluation independently reviews, evaluates, and on CI ﬁeld operations, program areas, and headquarters sections in a fair objective manner. Review and Program Evaluation identiﬁes risks, emerging issues and best practices which affect CI; assess CI’s leadership and ability to manage and mitigate risk; evaluate CI operations to ensure in- vestigative alignment with the Compliance Strategy; and to ensure with established policies and prior TIGTA, GAO, and RPE recommendations. (

) The Office of IO enhances CI’s ability to gather information located beyond borders by developing and maintaining relationships with our foreign partners through the strategic placement of CI personnel around the world. The Office of IO ensures CI’s ﬁnancial expertise is brought to bear on the most international tax, narcotics, transnational organized crimes, and counterterror- ism cases. (
) The Office of IO includes the following sections: • International Field Operations • NCT Organized Crime (

) International Field Operations ensures international law enforcement tion between foreign governments and CI ﬁeld offices as it relates to investigating potential criminal violations of the Internal Revenue Code and related ﬁnancial crimes. Criminal Investigation supports international case by maintaining Special Agent Attachés in strategic international locations. attachés facilitate the exchange of information with our international tax and law enforcement partners. (

) Narcotics and Counterterrorism provide policy guidance, operational tion and investigative support to CI ﬁeld offices. The NCT liaisons with agencies and national task forces to provide inter-agency coordination, de- conﬂiction, investigative analytical support, intelligence products, and guidance on a vast landscape of NCT and money laundering related cases. (

) The Office of Operations, Policy, and Support provides direction, oversight, support to the CI ﬁeld offices, writes and reviews operational policies, and recommendations to the Chief’s Office and extensively collaborates with our internal and external stakeholders in accomplishing the overall Criminal gation mission. (

) The Office of Operations, Policy and Support includes the following sections: a. Financial Crimes b. National Forensic Laboratory c. Special Investigative Techniques d. Warrants and Forfeiture e. Treasury Liaison (

) The Financial Crimes section oversees many domestic tax and ﬁnancial program areas including: fraud referral programs, bankruptcy fraud, ﬁnancial institution fraud, abusive tax schemes, money laundering, Bank Secrecy Act violations, and oversight of Financial Crimes Task Forces. The Fi
EN is assigned to this section and works directly with Fi
EN on common trends and analysis of ﬁnancial crimes Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Review and Program Evaluation identiﬁes risks, emerging issues and best practices which affect CI; assess CI’s leadership effectiveness, and ability to manage and mitigate risk; evaluate CI operations to ensure in
vestigative alignment with the Compliance Strategy; and to ensure compliance with established policies and prior TIGTA, GAO, and RPE recommendations.

page (
) National Forensic Laboratory is made up of three teams which include the entiﬁc Services, Design and Technology and Data Processing Center. (
) Special Investigative Techniques has oversight responsibilities for the authori- zation of undercover operations, witness protection, electronic surveillance informants. (

) Warrants and Forfeiture administers the asset forfeiture program and of fugitives. The TEOAF Liaison is assigned to this section and works directly with TEOAF in processing forfeiture packages and overseeing an annual budget given to CI in direct support of our ﬁnancial investigations. (
) The Treasury Liaison is IRS-CI’s direct line to the U.S. Department of the Treasury. The Liaison collaborates extensively on initiatives involving and international ﬁnancial fraud. (

) The Office of RCC supports the CI mission by identifying and developing criminal tax schemes for the purpose of referring and supporting high-impact criminal tax and related ﬁnancial investigations. By utilizing a multi-faceted approach, CI creates an enhanced enforcement presence among tax ners, tax preparers, and other third parties in an effort to reduce return preparer fraud. Cybercrime investigations will be conducted in three broad areas: core/traditional tax crimes, related ﬁnancial crimes, and Transnational Organized Crime Financing, including narcotics and terrorism support. (
) The Office of RCC includes the following sections: • Operations, Scheme Development & Support • Program Analysis & Operational Support • Cyber Crimes (

) Operations, Scheme Development & Support Section support the RCC by analyzing data to assist the ﬁeld offices with identifying and developing impact investigations. This section will also create policy and assist national program areas in the furtherance of CI’s overall mission of investigating potential criminal violations and tax compliance. Operations, Scheme ment & Support have SDCs located across the country. (

) Program Analysis & Operational Support supports RCC’s mission by oversight, data analytics, and development of requirements while maintaining the integrity of scheme development, investigative systems and applications. This mission will be achieved through the use of human and artiﬁcial intelli- gence and collaboration with stakeholders while partnering with RCC’s Cyber as well as Operations, Scheme Development & Support by providing the following: • Technical training and oversight • Big data/link analytics • Statistical analysis • Identiﬁcation and development of system rules & requirements (

) The Cyber Crimes section addresses the many challenges cyber criminals present in protecting the IRS and taxpayers from illicit acts violating our tax code. Cyber Crimes supports ﬁeld investigations involving cyber-dependent cyber-enabled criminal schemes by employing resources and experts in the cyber realm, including cryptocurrency and dark web technology. Cyber Internal Revenue Manual

• Big data/link analytics • Statistical analysis • Identiﬁcation and development of system rules & requirements (

) The Cyber Crimes section addresses the many challenges cyber criminals present in protecting the IRS and taxpayers from illicit acts violating our tax code. Cyber Crimes supports ﬁeld investigations involving cyber-dependent or cyber-enabled criminal schemes by employing resources and experts in the cyber realm, including cryptocurrency and dark web technology. Cyber Crimes
will also provide critical training to enhance the skillsets of CI personnel and combat the evolving aspects of cybercrime.
combat the evolving aspects of cybercrime. (

) The Office of Strategy develops and supports CI programs and action plans deliver strategic objectives. The Office of Strategy is also responsible for: • Researching criminal compliance issues to support the development of strategic priorities and improve operational effectiveness. • Formulating, administering, and executing the CI ﬁnancial plan consis- tent with national priorities. • Developing and delivering CI Law enforcement training consistent with national enforcement strategies and recognized training accreditation standards. • Implementing IRS Strategic HR programs and support CI speciﬁc human resource needs, including the development and of policies and programs. • Coordinating the implementation of Treasury law enforcement policies and special programs which impact CI. (
) The Office of Strategy includes the following branches: • Finance • HR • NCITA • PR&A (

) Finance provides overall policy and guidance on the ﬁnancial management of CI resources and ensures that all acquisition-related requirements and sibilities are met. The ﬁnancial management responsibilities include management and oversight of the current ﬁscal year’s ﬁnancial plan, ment of next ﬁscal year’s ﬁnancial plan and formulation of the future ﬁscal budget requests. Budget Execution of the current ﬁscal year’s ﬁnancial plan includes developing current ﬁscal year ﬁnancial operating policy and for all CI ﬁeld and HQ offices. This involves management of all labor and labor resources, appropriated and reimbursable, including asset forfeiture funding. In addition, Finance provides operational procurement guidance for CI ﬁeld and HQ offices. This involves setting policy for a wide range of activi- ties, including: purchase cardholders, purchase card approving officials, and acceptance, acquisition planning, and contract management. Finance works closely with IRS Procurement, to make sure all required equipment, supplies, and services are acquired in the most efficient, effective manner possible. (

) Human Resources is the BOD-based HR organization for CI. Human Resources is responsible for all of CI’s hiring, as well as implementing wide HR programs and processes, developing unique policy to meet the of CI, and provides HR program oversight on behalf of CI. (

) The NCITA is dedicated to fostering the highest levels of professionalism and ethical behavior throughout the CI’s workforce. The NCITA is divided into two sections: Training Operations and Strategy. Training Operations is for planning, organizing, coordinating and delivering a full range of learning and education products and programs for Basic and International Training. Training Strategy is responsible for the policies and procedures that adhere Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
Z
The Office of Strategy develops and supports CI programs and action plans to deliver strategic objectives. The Office of Strategy is also responsible for:

Researching criminal compliance issues to support the development strategic priorities and improve operational effectiveness. Formulating, administering, and executing the CI ﬁnancial plan tent with national priorities. Developing and delivering CI Law enforcement training consistent national enforcement strategies and recognized training accreditation standards. Implementing IRS Strategic HR programs and support CI speciﬁc human resource needs, including the development and of policies and programs. Coordinating the implementation of Treasury law enforcement policies and special programs which impact CI.
page the NCITA foundation for accreditation and supports the Course Unit, Leadership Development, Use of Force, and the Internal Management Document Program. (

) Planning, Research & Analysis develops and supports CI’s programs and action plans to deliver strategic objectives. This is accomplished through objective, high-quality data analysis, and operational and statistical studies. The information provides CI’s leaders the tools needed to make data-driven decisions required to measure and monitor CI’s impact on compliance. (

) Technology Operations and Investigative Services operates and maintains computer network, develops long-range IT strategies, plans and delivers the products associated with the long term strategies, evaluates the technical aspects of network software and hardware, and recovers and analyzes gative digital evidence. (
) The Office of TOIS includes the following sections: • Business Systems Development • Cybersecurity • EC • PMAC • Technical Operations Center • User Support (

) The Business Systems Development office is charged to identify and manage the delivery of business improvement and IT projects in support of the TOIS mission and the fulﬁllment of the CI vision and strategic mission. (

) Cybersecurity is responsible for IT Security, primarily the development and compliance of security policies and facilitating data spill clean-up and activities. In addition, the IT Security Team develops policies speciﬁc to CI interprets general security policies as they apply to CI. (

) Electronic Crimes supports IRS Special Agents in the collection and analysis digital evidence. Computer Investigative Specialists participate in search warrants with investigating agents and are responsible for the seizure and cessing of evidence contained in various types of digital media. The Crimes Laboratory, located in Woodbridge, VA, leads CI in the forensic tion, preservation, investigative analysis, and reporting of digital and cyber evidence. (

) The PMAC office is responsible for oversight for the CI governance boards CI’s demand prioritization process. In addition, PMAC coordinates budget for- mulation of core funding from IRS-IT in support of CI software and hardware, as well as coordinating TOIS/TEOAF funding with IRS-IT for new IT develop- ment. (
) The Technical Operations Center plans, implements, and maintains secure enforcement computer systems through the use of innovative and leading technologies. (
) User Support provides information technology support to CI users around the world. Internal Revenue Manual
The Technical Operations Center plans, implements, and maintains secure law enforcement computer systems through the use of innovative and leading edge
) There are four Directors, Field Operations covering the North, South, Mid- states, and West. (

) The Directors, Field Operations supervise the ﬁeld office SACs and oversee the ﬁeld office operations under their jurisdiction. In conjunction with the the Directors, Field Operations plan, develop, direct, and implement a hensive criminal investigation program for their area that enhances compliance, ensures consistency in taxpayer treatment, and continuously improves business systems and processes. (
) The management team in the individual ﬁeld offices consists of SACs, and SSAs. The duties and responsibilities of these managers are described in IRM
, Resource Guide for Managers.
The management team in the individual ﬁeld offices consists of SACs, ASACs, and SSAs. The duties and responsibilities of these managers are described in IRM 1.4.9, Resource Guide for Managers.
